title: 104_hr831
content:
SECTION 1. PERMANENT EXTENSION AND INCREASE OF DEDUCTION FOR HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS OF SELF-EMPLOYED INDIVIDUALS. The deduction for health insurance costs of self-employed individuals is permanently extended and increased from 25% to 30%. Effective dates for the extension and increase are specified. Subchapter O of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing part V related to FCC policy changes. Sections 1245(b)(5) and 1250(d)(5) are also amended to remove references to FCC policies. The effective date for these amendments is specified as January 17, 1995, for sales and exchanges. The amendments made by this section do not apply to sales or exchanges under binding contracts entered into before January 16, 1995, if the FCC tax certificate was applied for or issued by that date. The term "FCC tax certificate" refers to a certificate issued by the Federal Communications Commission for tax purposes related to the Internal Revenue Code. Material terms of a contract are not considered contingent on the issuance of an FCC tax certificate if they allow for a price increase of up to 10 percent. Special rules apply to involuntary conversions. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULES RELATING TO INVOLUNTARY CONVERSIONS. Amends Section 1033 of the Internal Revenue Code to state that nonrecognition does not apply if a corporation acquires replacement property from a related person. The amendment to Section 1033 of the Internal Revenue Code specifies that nonrecognition does not apply if replacement property is acquired from a related person. This rule does not apply if the related person acquired the replacement property from an unrelated person. The effective date for this amendment is February 6, 1995. The amendment to Section 1033 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for sales or exchanges to implement microwave relocation policy before January 1, 2000, certified by the Federal Communications Commission. SEC. 4. DENIAL OF EARNED INCOME CREDIT FOR INDIVIDUALS HAVING EXCESSIVE INVESTMENT INCOME.
    Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to deny the credit if the taxpayer's disqualified income exceeds $2,350 for the taxable year. The amendment applies to sales or exchanges after March 14, 1995. The taxpayer's income for the taxable year must exceed $2,350 to be considered disqualified income, which includes interest, dividends, and certain types of rental or royalty income not derived in the ordinary course of business. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Section 13442(b) of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 is amended to extend the special rule for certain group health plans to December 31, 1995. Additionally, a study of expatriation tax is mentioned. The Joint Committee on Taxation will study issues related to proposals affecting expatriation taxation, including current law effectiveness, expatriation for tax avoidance, constitutional restrictions, human rights principles, capital flow effects, tax treaty impacts, and trust interests. The Joint Committee on Taxation will study proposals related to expatriation taxation, including trust interests, potential double taxation issues, impact on trade policy objectives, administrability, and existing law problems. The Chief of Staff will report the study results to the Chairmen of the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Finance by June 1, 1995.
